subject: Re: [Read_Alphabet] I can't assign ah/awe/ox, and the helpful chart made it worse.  Help?
msgSnippet: ... They are all the same for some people, basically in the western U.S. If you tell us where you live (or grew up), we may be able to help further. ... The
messageBody:
fctarbox3 scripsit:

> I'm not very good with IPA vowels, but I'm pretty confident Ah is
> supposed to be the a in father. But when I look at the template
> Othermale has in the files section, my choice for ah includes palm,
> lot, thought, and cloth, none of which sound like the a in father to me.

They are all the same for some people, basically in the western U.S.
If you tell us where you live (or grew up), we may be able to help further.

> I think for palm I'm the victim of assimilation; my dialect has absorbed
> the 'lm' so thoroughly into the preceding vowel that it's stuck there
> forever, I've yet to find a word with that same vowel that wasn't in the
> "alm" context. You might convince me that palm is just AWE+m, but...

The word's not ideal, because some people pronounce the "l" though most
do not. But this whole group is miscellaneous: some words that kept their
sounds through the Great Vowel Shift, like "father"; the "alm" words;
and various foreign words like "salaam", "Brahms", "sonata", "iguana".

> If I say them together long enough, I can make lot and father come
> out close enough that I can pretend I'm imagining the difference,
> but I can do the same thing for lot and cloth, and then do the same
> thing again for cloth and thaw, and I *cannot* do the same thing for
> thaw and father.

This sounds like you are from the eastern U.S., where "lot" and "father" have
the same vowel quality (the vowel in "lot" is automatically shorter
than in "father" because the syllable is closed by the final "t"),
and so do "cloth" and "thaw".

If that's true, you really do have only two vowels for the three Read
letters, which means you simply have to learn when to use Ox and when to
use Ah. Basically, it depends on whether the written word in ordinary
spelling has "o" or "a".

> I can travel in a similar direction towards thought, so I end up with
> a triangle, father-thought-thaw, or minimally paired, pause-paws.
> It's tempting to think three vowels, three letters, but if Ah is father
> and Awe is thaw, then thought would have to be ox, and that's just
> not right, because thought is a diphthong, and ox isn't meant to be.

Are you sure? "Thought" is *written* with two letters, and it is
subject to automatic shortening for the same reason as "lot", but the
vowel quality of "thought" and "thaw" is usually the same.

--
Don't be so humble. You're not that great. John Cowan
--Golda Meir cowan@...
